item.title: U.S. Frees Last of the ‘Cuban Five,’ Part of a 1990s Spy Ring
item.description: Three members of the Cuban Five — part of a spy ring that infiltrated exile groups in Florida in the 1990s — were released from prison as part of the sudden diplomatic thaw in relations.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: A billboard in Havana with Fidel Castro and the Cuban Five, left, spies who infiltrated exile groups in South Florida and who were also freed on Wednesday.

item.title: Yemen’s Children Go Hungry as Its Government Weakens
item.description: The country, which has one of the highest rates of child malnutrition, is struggling through a failing transition to democracy and facing a rebel uprising.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Huda bin Nasser with her malnourished daughter, Hadiya, at their home in the village of Sheikhain, Yemen.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: John Osburg on China’s Wealthy Turning to Spiritualism
item.description: The author says that some Chinese are genuinely interested in spiritual transformation and in becoming better, more moral people. But there’s also an element of social distinction that’s feeding this trend.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Flight Attendant Kicked Off Korean Air Flight Alleges Cover-Up
item.description: A senior steward on Flight 86 claims that the airline and the government tried to coerce crew members into lying about an airline executive’s outburst over macadamia nuts.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: No Major Backlash After Sydney Siege, but Muslims Are Fearful
item.description: After the hostage standoff, Australian Muslims worry that the country is one attack away from reversing their growing but tenuous acceptance in the wider population.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Letter From China: Reporters in China Say Media Freeze Is Intensifying
item.description: Progress on visa renewals for journalists obscures what many correspondents say is a mounting hostility toward Western media outlets operating in China.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Putin Blames Outside Forces for Economic Woes
item.description: During his annual news conference, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia discussed the recent crisis in his nation’s currency.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took questions during his annual news conference in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Indonesia Takes Tough Stance in Fighting Illegal Fishing
item.description: In recent weeks, the Indonesian Navy has seized and sunk dozens of foreign fishing boats from neighboring countries like Vietnam and Malaysia.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY HUTTON

item.title: Zambian Officials Call for Acting President’s Ouster, Sharpening Power Struggle
item.description: Guy Scott, Africa’s only white leader, has refused to heed demands for him to quit, accusing opponents of treason.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: South Koreans Take Up Cause of Japanese in Nobel Quest
item.description: Prominent South Koreans started an effort on Thursday backing Japanese supporters of a constitutional provision that renounces war.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: European Markets Eye an Austerity-Weary Greece
item.description: There is a general sense that Europe could survive a breakup with Greece, if it came to that, with relatively minimal damage, thanks to an array of recent regulatory changes and a renewed commitment among leaders.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Alexis Tsipras, leader of the Greek opposition leftist party Syriza, in Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Mass Grave May Hold Bodies of 230 Members of Anti-ISIS Tribe
item.description: More than 230 bodies of people believed to have been killed by Islamic State militants have been found in a mass grave in eastern Syria, activists said Wednesday.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Agencies Warn of Hunger in Ebola Zone
item.description: The Ebola outbreak ravaging West Africa could double the number of people facing hunger in the three worst-affected countries to more than one million by March, two United Nations agencies warned Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: New Premier Is Appointed
item.description: Somalia’s president appointed a new prime minister on Wednesday, naming Omar Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke to succeed the prime minister ousted by Parliament this month
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: China: Dalai Lama Hints Spiritual Line Might Come to an End With Him
item.description: The Dalai Lama, Tibet’s exiled spiritual leader, told the BBC he would rather there be no Dalai Lama than that a “stupid” successor replace him.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Palestinians Make Strides Toward Draft Resolution at U.N.
item.description: After a day of intense lobbying, the Palestinians persuaded Arab diplomats to support a draft Security Council resolution that is aimed at the full withdrawal of Israeli forces from the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: From the Archives: Mistrust Erodes Relations Between U.S. and Cuba
item.description: For more than 50 years and through 10 presidencies, U.S.-Cuba relations have been characterized by the animosity between Washington and Fidel Castro.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: DealBook: Ruble Crisis Is Testing Russia’s Resources
item.description: The country’s finance ministry said it was prepared to sell as much as $7 billion of its foreign currency reserves to support the ruble, which an official called “extremely undervalued.”
item.dc:creator: By JENNY ANDERSON
item.media:description: Prime Minister Dmitry A. Medvedev of Russia, center, held a meeting on economic issues on Wednesday in Moscow.

item.title: Journey to Reconciliation Visited Worlds of Presidents, Popes and Spies
item.description: The deal that restored full diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba ultimately rested with a spy swap.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Obama speaking with Cuba’s president, Raúl Castro, on Tuesday. On Wednesday, Mr. Obama ordered the restoration of full diplomatic relations.

item.title: Snow Is Down and Heat Is Up in the Arctic, Report Says
item.description: The Arctic continued to warm faster than the rest of the globe, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Arctic Report Card.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG
item.media:description: As sea ice retreats, more sunlight reaches the upper layers of the sea, leading to more phytoplankton blooms, seen here in the Bering Sea this fall.
